comments.commentBody: You clearly have no clue as to the range and type of nonprofits that exist and do important work beyond the scope of your simplistic list. I humbly suggest you do some research before you make such sweeping statements.

I think the better solution would be to abolish non-profits altogether and create of list tax-exempt activities. That would end all of the ambiguity and ensure that non-social welfare activities (including political activities) are taxed.

So, things like donated food, expenses associated with preparation and distribution of donated food, homeless shelter expenses, adoption service expenses, uncompensated medical care, etc. would be tax exempt. Everything else: you pay taxes.
Obama and Reid's recent leadership actions have made me happy enough to do a jig. Instead of being so miserable and negative, you should try joining the happy club.
This comment should be highlighted. Ordinary folks are not heard.
My sentiments exactly!!  Thanks.
why should I pay taxes yet these political non profits do not?  Politics in not a non profit endeavor- has nothing to do with free speech but with political corruption

It's a slippery slope to start banning non-profits from speaking of politics.  To paraphrase on old poem, "First, they came for  the gypsies, and no one spoke, then, they came for the jews, and no one spoke, ..... now they come for me, will anyone speak?"

It seems to me you prefer a government of the plutocrats by the plutocrats for the plutocrats because they are the ones that have the greatest amount of influence in our political system. Their slogan is never  mind the people in the middle class or the poor who do not have the money to support or "buy" the candidates or influence a political party. This rule has nothing to do with "free speech" and is all about  stopping the subversive behavior by these plutocrats. Lastly, this rule does not favor one party over another but cuts both ways and does not choke political activity of either party.  What it tries to do is cut off the vast amounts of money channeled anonymously, by people like the Koch Brothers, to the political candidates or parties through these bogus organizations.

Another example of this Administration's desire to choke political activity with which it disagrees.  The right to free speech, the right to govern ourselves, and the right to association are not three discrete rights, which Obama can decide are allottable in what quota to whom, but a basic unity of civil rights,
Yes, you are the only one who looks at this and sees Hitler and Munich.  Yes, you are exaggerating.

Yep, and those separate foundations always kept their money the correct account? And I guess you are not on the same Democrat matching funds email list I get from Soros asking for funds to help Obama's people defeat Bachmann.

I was a founding officer of the NH ACLU affiliate, back in the late 1960's. Because ACLU engages in extensive lobbying--which mostly consists of testifying before legislative committees on matters affecting civil liberties and being available to answer questions from legislators--the main organization did not apply for 501c(3) status. We had a separate 501c(3) foundation, NHCLUF, to support litigation. But the most important thing that organization did was educate people. Police departments became highly sensitized to ACLU advice after the lawsuit was filed and town lawyers told them how things stood.

Against that background, knowing how some people might react to an organization which protected long hair, hippies, blacks--yes, that was the "progressive" term at that time--draft refusers and protesters, we published only the names of our officers, staff and Board. But we, as an organization, said nothing about candidates--except those we named as defendants in lawsuits usually not directly related to their candidacy.

What these recent 501c(4) registrants have been doing is a perversion of that status, determined to keep people from knowing the millions the Koch brothers and Sheldon Adelson spend to defeat certain candidates. We should criminalize such behavior, instead of letting them hide it. If that means their businesses will suffer boycotts and that people will refuse to work for them, that is an appropriate consequence for their corrupt attempts to buy elections.

No it does not make poverty go away. But neither does denying support to the poor. How exactly to you expect those who are too poor to get enough food to "move to states and cities that do try to provide adequately?" Dealing with the problem of poverty is a separate issue that must be addressed, but being inhumane doesn't get us any closer to a solution.

A solution starts with realizing that our present economy is a failure. It doesn't begin to meet the requirements of an economy. It provides far too few jobs, and far too much inequality. Until a solution is found and implemented, it is totally reasonable to tax money away from those at the top and distribute it to those at the bottom from whom it has been stolen.
And for those communities which drive the poor away, to where do they drive them?  The grave?  Roadkill?   It's not as if the poor have anywhere to go but where they are.

Picking cotton was labor-intensive until we figured out how to mechanize it. At that point cotton-growing areas were faced with a serious surplus of labor. They could have taught their cotton pickers to do something else and lured that other sort of work to their areas, and help the ex cotton pickers to survive until the changes were achieved.

They did not do this. They set benefits very low, called the ex cotton pickers lazy for not finding other ways to survive, and basically pushed them to leave for other locales. The receiving locales were often swamped by too many people not well prepared to play productive roles, and the cotton growing areas pointed to these problems as proving their superior insight about what the ex cotton pickers were good for.

Some states, counties, cities, and other areas will decide to give their poor and hungry reason to move. States and cities will not supplement Federal help, and some of their poor will move to states and cities that do try to provide adequately. In this way they will reduce their poverty problem.

Areas that do not drive their poor away will have to develop a strategy for dealing with poverty in the whole country that does not involve merely taking in the nation's poor and caring for them. The strategy of providing Federal benefits so the poor can afford to be poor where they are, does not make the problem of poverty go away.

Nicholas Nickleby, I'm not an economist, but even a cursory Google search reveals that you are not revealing the entire story. For one thing, Romer later pushed back at the suggestion that her study supported the idea that bringing down the deficit had to be done solely through spending cuts: "The economic evidence doesn’t support the anti-tax view. Both tax increases and spending cuts will tend to slow the recovery in the near term, but spending cuts will likely slow it more. Over the longer term, sensible tax increases will probably do less damage to economic growth and productivity than cuts in government investment."

http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/business/economy/03view.html

JoanneB writes, "Meanwhile, it'll be great for all the businesses in SF if tourists again return en masse."

They never left. Hotels remain the biggest revenue generator for the city. I don't really have a problem with the misguided Randians on this board who relentlessly preach juvenile libertarianism, but I'd rather really not read deliberate disinformation and untruths in these comments.

I am sorry but I am totally confused.
Are you saying that you are a landlord of a non-rent-controlled building?
If not, I don't understand what you love about rent control or why you are collecting "extremely lucrative rents."

I worked for a few years in San Francisco, fortunately just in between the two big booms, so I was able to rent a lovely condo with a view (and a garage!!!) for a price I could afford. But even so, it was very expensive living in the city.
A co-worker with a lower salary than mine (different job categories) lived in a rent-controlled apartment in what was once a single family Victorian mansion. She had been there for decades. Without the monkey of high rents on her back, she was able to afford frequent overseas vacations I could only dream about - 5 star hotels all the way. I did not begrudge her but, geesh, was I envious!

I used to work in a tech company and I have to agree. It was a shock to me at first then I got used to it. People would walk down the hallway and wouldn't even have any eye contact when it's just two people walking down a narrow hallway, and that was before the day of cell phones.

Having a soul requires eye contact with complete strangers.

Many high tech people cannot manage that. I believe they can reclaim their souls, but need massive help to untether from the machines.

It's not a ridiculous thought.
That's the issue in a nutshell:  it's always, always all about you.

I sympathize with the plight of tenants having to move on account of landlords wanting to sell, but on the other hand, I can't sympathize with the notion that landlords should be required to be landlords forever.  Rental property (well, heck, most real estate) is an investment. Rental property is also a lot of work.  Who can really fault a property owner for eventually wanting to cash in on an investment?  I don't see any reason to demonize the landlord (and no, I'm not a landlord.)

Too many young mega rich think they are more deserving, more intelligent (even than the 98 year old who gets evicted). The actuality is they are simply luckier.

Money isn't everything, but to many, it is the only goal that makes them feel like 'winners'. Not pretty in any light.

For 130 million working Americans, the Trans-Pacific Partnership is, as Minnesota Rep. Keith Ellison (D) described so well, the "largest corporate power grab you never heard of."

After 19 rounds of negotiations between the United States, Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore and Vietnam, TPP remains a mystery to everyone except government trade negotiators and the corporate lobbyists who get to read all the proposals.

Even Members of Congress have real no idea of what's involved in the negotiations.

Rep. Alan Grayson (D-Fla.), has seen some of the proposals. TPP is "a punch in the face to the middle class of America ... but I'm not allowed to tell you why," he said.

In addition to the secrecy, trade negotiators are counting on "fast track" authority, which blocks any changes or amendments to the trade deal and only allows for an "up or down" vote by Congress. Stopping or changing fast track is the only real way to change TPP.

TPP is bad for working families, because, like nearly every other trade agreement that's been negotiated by the U.S. in the past 20 years, TPP isn't concerned with U.S. workers or jobs. Every other nation starts out with jobs and the economy as their priorities. The U.S. unfortunately has a different focus, and looks at trade in terms of national security and global corporate interests, not ensuring the economic well-being of working families.
Flying in international airspace is not belligerence.
I agree with you about the nationalist trend in China, and it is not great. But I don't think China can become another Nazi Germany. Very different people.

Liz B.
My daughter and I would like your address. And what time should we be there??
I do have a springform pan.....

The pecan pie looks lovely; it's cooling now.

As MTF, it's table tennis, not pingpong.

And in answer to the direct question, Will is on a quest to play table tennis every single day this year and is filming himself in the process. So, while I can't guarantee he'll play next Thanksgiving, I can say with great confidence that he'll be playing this Thanksgiving.
Ping-Pong spelled backwards is Gnip-Gnop.

One time my sister insisted on our jointly doing the Christmas goose thing, complete with chestnut dressing. Worst Holiday Meal Ever, plus it took all day.

Jules's meal is very short on veggies and trimmings. No cranberries. No pickles. God knows, he probably got canned GRAVY. I've heard of such happenings.....the stuff(ing) of nightmares!

Oh well. It's only a Wednesday.

Brown stock done. DHubby got home with almost all the necessities....but bought frozen biscuits vs yeast biscuits. "Don't all biscuits have yeast in them?"......Um, no...... so I am punished for trying to duck an extra prep. Tomorrow the YEAST biscuit dough will also be on the task list.

I am left with questions: how is a pecantart different from a pecan pie?
Should the puzzle come before the turkey is in the oven?
If the Thanksgiving puzzle has already appeared, what's on the menu for Thursday?
Does Will play pingpong on Thanksgiving?
Japan has approved itself a Bully in the north east Asia.  Japan has territorial conflicts with all of it's neighbors!

It is a joke to state that 'it is the responsibility of politicians and real estate developers to support the middle and working classes."  In San Francisco it is exactly the real estate developers who are pushing change in the city, constructing massive condo and rental buildings affordable only for people earning $100,000 a year at a minimum.  Politicians?  So busy encouraging the development of crowd-fueled sports arenas like the proposed Warriors arena planned to be dropped on the city's beautiful waterfront with the potential of massive traffic problems, they have little time to really address the issues of poor and middle income folks.  When locals protest, the developers and politicians call them NIMBYs as though that was a pejorative term.  Well NIMBYs have their place and they need to have their say which is, be careful of my backyard because you are in grave danger of ruining it.

It is news like this one that paints China as a bully that caused Chinese protest in LA against Jimmy Kimmel's supposed funny show where a boy burst out 'Kill them all!' when asked by his host 'what should we do with China as our biggest creditor?'  The media's emphases on our debt to China without mentioning Japan to whom we owe almost as much (with only a little over 100 billion less) that inflate unnecessary enmity toward China.  It would be informative to readers if the article had also mentioned our own and other major powers' aircraft ID zones.

Chinese aircraft can fly off the coast of Japan, which is just as effective ...

"A [Japanese Defense Ministry] spokesman said two Chinese reconnaissance planes had flown within about 25 miles of what Japan considers its airspace, Reuters said."
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/24/world/asia/china-warns-of-action-again...
Come on, when all these countries and China you mentioned were fighting for territories back then, America didn't even exist. Mind your own problems. Let them solve their problems by themselves.
